did.unittitle: Rockefeller Foundation records, projects, SG 1.1, Series 300 Latin America - Series 833 Lebanon

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Rockefeller Foundation was established by act of the New York State Legislature approved by the Governor on May 14, 1913, "to promote the well-being of mankind throughout the world." Between 1913 and 1928 the China Medical Board, the International Health Board, and the Division of Medical Education functioned as divisions of the Foundation, concentrating on the administration of programs in public health and medical education. A Division of Studies was created in 1923 to handle projects outside the medical field. These early years were experimental as the new foundation studied the methods of philanthropy and explored its relationships with other Rockefeller boards.

Although the Rockefeller Foundation is the largest and best known philanthropy founded by the Rockefeller family, it was neither the first nor the last to be established. The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (1901), the General Education Board (1902), the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission for the Eradication of Hookworm Disease (1909), and the Bureau of Social Hygiene (1911) all existed earlier. When the Foundation was created, the Sanitary Commission was disbanded. After the establishment of the Foundation, the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial (1918) and the International Education Board (1923) were created.

The Rockefeller boards and their programs were reconsidered and reorganized in 1927-1928 in order to avoid overlapping programs. The International Health Board of the Foundation was disbanded and an International Health Division was organized. The China Medical Board, Inc., was established as a separately incorporated institution, and the China Medical Board of the Foundation ceased to exist. The Division of Studies was dropped and the Division of Medical Education was phased out. The Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial was combined with the Foundation and the Spelman Fund of New York was chartered to continue activities of the LSRM that were not absorbed by the Foundation. The International Education Board was disbanded.

As a result of this reorganization, the Foundation adopted a program which included public health work (administered by the IHD), the advancement of knowledge in the medical and natural sciences (in part taken over from the IEB), the social sciences (formerly the field of the LSRM), and the humanities and arts (shared with the GEB). The Rockefeller Institute and the Bureau of Social Hygiene were not affected by the reorganization. The program adopted by the Foundation at this time remained basically the same for the next twenty years.

As its files accumulated, the Foundation maintained a card index recording the names of institutional and individual grantees and correspondents. A microfilm copy of this index is available at the Archive Center.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The project files are arranged in series according to country. Each country or geographical area was assigned a three-digit number by RF staff. In addition, letters signifying program areas are used: for example, "A" indicates a grant in the Medical Sciences, and "C" Nursing. Material is organized within these letter/program subdivisions alphabetically by grant title. A grant title usually consists of a heading that includes the name of the institution or individual that received the grant. Thus each grant, or project, is filed individually in one or more folders.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Confidential material in this record group has been segregated and is inaccessible. Each pertinent file is open to research, and physical removal of the segregated material within each file is not necessary. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact a RAC archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of material relating to more than one country in Latin America. Most of the series is composed of files of recipients of Foundation Agricultural Scholarships in the 1950's (300 D).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
300 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
300 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
300 R Humanities and arts
300 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The majority of projects treated in this material are in the medical and natural sciences and date from the 1940's and 1950's. Prominent institutions are the Institute of Biochemical Research, the University of Buenos Aires, the National University of the Litoral, the Institute of Plant Science, and the University of Cordoba. Early files, generated by Foundation officers, include a report by Richard M. Pearce, "Medical Education in Argentina," (1917, 1925) and reports by Nelson C. Davis, Persis Putnum, E. R. Rickard, and R. C. Shannon.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
301 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
301 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
301 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing.
301 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
301 I Malaria
301 M Respiratory diseases
301 R Humanities and arts
301 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of records dating primarily from 1930 to 1950, mainly documenting Rockefeller Foundation public health programs. "Medical Education in Bolivia" (1926), by Robert A. Lambert, is part of a worldwide investigation of medical education undertaken by the Foundation in the 1920's.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries as follows:
303 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
303 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
303 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
303 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
303 O Yellow fever

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early Brazilian material (1916-1940) reflects The Rockefeller Foundation's commitment to public health and hygiene, including work to control diseases as hookworm, malaria, and yellow fever. Yellow fever was a dominant concern of The Foundation in Brazil from 1927 to 1955; the Foundation operated two laboratories in Bahia and Rio de Janeiro. The voluminous yellow fever files contain staff diaries and journals, laboratory diaries, records of surveys and tests, and case histories. Other early grants went to the Sao Paulo Faculty of Medicine and schools of nursing in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. In the 1940s and 1950s agricultural projects became a major concern. During this period, grants to programs in the natural sciences, particularly at the University of Sao Paolo, were also numerous.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Twelve subseries as follows:
305 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
305 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
305 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
305 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
305 H Hookworm
305 I Malaria
305 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
305 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
305 O Yellow fever
305 R Humanities and arts
305 S Social sciences
305 V Virus studies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early Brazilian material (1916-1940) reflects The Rockefeller Foundation's commitment to public health and hygiene, including work to control diseases as hookworm, malaria, and yellow fever. Yellow fever was a dominant concern of The Foundation in Brazil from 1927 to 1955; the Foundation operated two laboratories in Bahia and Rio de Janeiro. The voluminous yellow fever files contain staff diaries and journals, laboratory diaries, records of surveys and tests, and case histories. Other early grants went to the Sao Paulo Faculty of Medicine and schools of nursing in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. In the 1940s and 1950s agricultural projects became a major concern. During this period, grants to programs in the natural sciences, particularly at the University of Sao Paolo, were also numerous.

scopecontent.p: Early Brazilian material (1916-1940) reflects The Rockefeller Foundation's commitment to public health and hygiene, including work to control diseases as hookworm, malaria, and yellow fever. Yellow fever was a dominant concern of The Foundation in Brazil from 1927 to 1955; the Foundation operated two laboratories in Bahia and Rio de Janeiro. The voluminous yellow fever files contain staff diaries and journals, laboratory diaries, records of surveys and tests, and case histories. Other early grants went to the Sao Paulo Faculty of Medicine and schools of nursing in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. In the 1940s and 1950s agricultural projects became a major concern. During this period, grants to programs in the natural sciences, particularly at the University of Sao Paolo, were also numerous.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Scholarly access to original archival material is permitted. User copies of microfilm are also available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The only material in Series 309, Chile, dating before the 1930's is a report on medical education, medical relief, and public health (1919) by Richard M. Pearce. Except for a few grants for projects in agriculture, the humanities, and medicine, which were funded in the 1930's, most Foundation support to Chile began in the 1940's and continued into the 1950's. Grants for agricultural and medical research at the University of Chile and the Catholic University predominate; public health projects were also supported.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
309 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
309 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
309 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
309 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
309 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
309 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
309 R Humanities and arts
309 S Social sciences

University of Chile - Williamson, L. M. - (Neurosurgery, Travel Grant)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Medical education in Colombia received Rockefeller Foundation attention with a general survey by Alan Gregg (1923) and a report by W. M. Monroe on medicine and natural sciences at the National University (1923). The Foundation was also involved in disease control in Colombia, beginning in 1919 with hookworm, 1923 with yellow fever, 1927 with malaria. From 1945 to 1955, most Foundation support went to agriculture research. Material on agriculture is located in 311 as well as in 311 D.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eleven subseries as follows:
311 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
311 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
311 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
311 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
311 H Hookworm
311 I Malaria
311 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
311 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
311 O Yellow fever
311 R Humanities and arts
311 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

317 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)

317 O Yellow fever
317 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These records relate almost solely to public health work in Guatemala in the early 1930's. The files also contain a report on medical education in Guatemala prepared in 1922; this report was part of a worldwide Foundation survey of medical education. In addition, there is material pertaining to a grant to the National Archeological Museum, 1945-1950.

arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
319 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
319 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
319 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administartion, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
319 R Humanities and arts

320 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The early (1920's) material in these files concerns the medical sciences and includes a report on medical education in Mexico which was part of a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education. Public health related records also begin in the 1920's and continue into the 1940's; these records concern Foundation work with typhoid fever, hookworm, malaria, and health demonstration units.

Records relating to the agricultural program in Mexico span the years from 1933 to 1956, with the bulk of the material dated between 1945 and 1955. In 1943, the Foundation launched its renowned Mexican agricultural program. This program administered by The Rockefeller Foundation, included research by resident Foundation staff to improve Mexico's major food crops; fellowships, scholarships, and travel grants to train Mexican agricultural scientists as well as scientists from other countries; and grants to universities and other institutions to support education and research in agricultural science. The agricultural program records are found in 323, with the exception of institutional grants which are located in 323 D. Additional records of the Foundation agricultural program in Mexico are located in RG 1.2, Series 323.

Files from the 1940's and 1950's also resulted from RF grants to institutions in the areas of medical research and education, the natural sciences (mathematics, chemistry, physics), and the humanities and social sciences (libraries and museums, history and anthropology, music).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Nine subseries as follows:
323 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
323 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
323 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
323 H Hookworm
323 I Malaria
323 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
323 Q Epidemiological investigations and studies
323 R Humanities and arts
323 S Social sciences

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional records of the Foundation agricultural program in Mexico are located in RG 1.2, Series 323.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Aside from a report on medical education in Nicaragua, which was part of a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education in the early 1920's, the files are mainly concerned with public health, including malaria control and health demonstration and laboratory units.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
325 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
325 I Malaria
325 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
325 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administartion, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the records in this series relate to health projection in Panama. Files concerning public health matters document grants for malaria studies, health demonstration and laboratories, and work on yellow fever and tuberculosis. There is also a file relating to Foundation support of a nursing school at the Santo Tomas Hospital, 1933-1945.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Six subseries as follows:
327 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
327 I Malaria
327 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
327 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administartion, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
327 O Yellow fever
327 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These records relate primarily to public health programs. The earliest files concern the medical sciences and include a report on medical education and public health in Paraguay. Later files (1924-1942) have to do with Foundation activity in the control of hookworm and yellow fever.

329 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest files, dealing with medical sciences, include a report (1926) which resulted from The Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide survey of medical education. Some public health material is present, including files relating to the ICA Health Service, the National Institute of Hygiene, malaria and yellow fever. The Foundation made grants in the medical sciences during the 1940's and 1950's to the University of San Marcos in Lima; it also supported agricultural and veterinary research in the 1950's at various institutions including the National School of Agriculture in La Molina and the University of San Marcos at Lima.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Nine subseries as follows:
331 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
331 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
331 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
331 I Malaria
331 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
331 K Health Services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
331 O Yellow fever
331 R Humanities and arts
331 S Social sciences

The Foundation made grants in the medical sciences during the 1940's and 1950's to the University of San Marcos in Lima; it also supported agricultural and veterinary research in the 1950's at various institutions including the National School of Agriculture in La Molina and the University of San Marcos at Lima.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains early (1920's) material on medical sciences, including a report on medical education in El Salvador; this report resulted from a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education. Later files concern public health demonstration units, a public health laboratory and malaria control.

arrangement.p: Five subseries as follows:
333 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
333 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
333 I Malaria
333 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
333 K Health Services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The majority of material in this series deals with grants to the Institute of Biological Sciences at Montevideo (1941-1925) under the direction of Clemente Estable. There is also a report (1917-1925) on medical education in Uruguay; this report resulted from a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education. In addition, the Foundation supported several natural science projects and a nursing school at the University of Montevideo during the 1940's and 1950's.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
337 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
337 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
337 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
337 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes files relating to the medical sciences, including a report on medical education in Venezuela; this report resulted from a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education in the 1920's. The Foundation also supported the National School of Nursing in Caracas from 1936 to 1951 and programs to control hookworm, malaria, and yellow fever from 1926-1952.

339 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
339 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
339 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
339 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
339 H Hookworm
339 I Malaria
339 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
339 O Yellow fever

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this series consists of a single file dealing with Foundation-supported fellowships through Great Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.

After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.
Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Nine subseries as follows:
401 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
401 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
401 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
401 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
401 E Fellowships, training awards

401 F Declinations (within program, or outside program but receiving more consideration than a flat declination, i.e. request circulated to a number of officers for opinion before declining; outside opinion solicited; considerable correspondence leading to the declination)
401 I Malaria
401 R Humanities and arts
401 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.

After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.
Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.
Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest material in this series treats the Foundation's interest in public health and medical education in the Republic of Ireland, including field units in Counties Cork, Donegal and Kildare. Later areas of interest included physics, nursing, and zoology and the humanities.
Material extending from 1950 to 1972 consists entirely of a historical record of the activities of the Irish Folklore Institute.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
403 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
403 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
403 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
403 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
403 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
403 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
403 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
403 R Humanities and arts

405 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)

405 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
405 S Social sciences

419 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The first Foundation grant to Canada was as part of a relief effort in Newfoundland (1914). As part of regular program oriented support, the Foundation supported various medical and public health projects, especially between 1920 and 1950. Dalhousie and McGill University, the Universities of Manitoba and Montreal, and various Provincial governments were the main beneficiaries of the Foundation's interests in these areas.

In the humanities, the Foundation gave grants for folklore studies, library surveys, and drama, mainly in the 1940's. Support for the social sciences came mainly through grants and fellowships administered by the Canadian social Science Research Council (1940-1957) and various universities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
427 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
427 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
427 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
427 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
427 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
427 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
427 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
427 R Humanities and arts
427 S Social sciences
427 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The first Foundation grant to Canada was as part of a relief effort in Newfoundland (1914). As part of regular program oriented support, the Foundation supported various medical and public health projects, especially between 1920 and 1950. Dalhousie and McGill University, the Universities of Manitoba and Montreal, and various Provincial governments were the main beneficiaries of the Foundation's interests in these areas.

In the humanities, the Foundation gave grants for folklore studies, library surveys, and drama, mainly in the 1940's. Support for the social sciences came mainly through grants and fellowships administered by the Canadian social Science Research Council (1940-1957) and various universities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest Foundation grants to Jamaica were made as part of its programs against hookworm disease and malaria and for development of public health facilities. The largest amount of Foundation activity here, however, was in the area of tuberculosis control (1931-1941). This series contains considerable material on that subject, including narrative and statistical reports and records of an x-ray unit funded by the Foundation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
437 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
437 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
437 H Hookworm
437 I Malaria
437 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
437 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
437 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
437 R Humanities and arts
437 T Tuberculosis
437 U Yaws

scopecontent.p: Early material in this series deals with a grant to the Imperial College of Tropical Diseases (1924-1933). The Foundation also conducted a malaria survey in this area during the 1940's. Most of the files in this series document the Foundation's activity in virus disease research on these islands (1952-1972).

451 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
451 V Virus studies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest Foundation grant to India (1913) was made to the All-India School of Hygiene and Public Health at Calcutta. This school continued to be the major institutional recipient of Foundation aid in the areas of public health and medical education until 1950.
Of particular interest in this series is a 30 volume manuscript survey and history of medical education in India by W. S. Carter (1926-1927).

During the 1930's and 1940's the Foundation supported various rural health programs, developmental aid to nursing, and a survey of librarianship during this period. From 1951 to 1971 the Foundation's main interest in India was expressed through its virus disease research program. Researchers should note that material covering virus research is filed under both 464 and 464 V.

The Foundation also funded public health and anti-malaria work in the independent Indian states of Mysore (464.1), Sawantwadi (464.4), and Travancore (464.5) from 1928 to 1944. After independence was granted India in 1947, these numerical designations were dropped from the Foundation's classification scheme.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
464 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
464 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
464 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
464 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
464 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
464 I Malaria
464 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
464 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
464 R Humanities and arts
464 V Virus studies

Of particular interest in this series is a 30 volume manuscript survey and history of medical education in India by W. S. Carter (1926-1927).

During the 1930's and 1940's the Foundation supported various rural health programs, developmental aid to nursing, and a survey of librarianship during this period. From 1951 to 1971 the Foundation's main interest in India was expressed through its virus disease research program. Researchers should note that material covering virus research is filed under both 464 and 464 V.

The Foundation also funded public health and anti-malaria work in the independent Indian states of Mysore (464.1), Sawantwadi (464.4), and Travancore (464.5) from 1928 to 1944. After independence was granted India in 1947, these numerical designations were dropped from the Foundation's classification scheme.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest Foundation grant to India (1913) was made to the All-India School of Hygiene and Public Health at Calcutta. This school continued to be the major institutional recipient of Foundation aid in the areas of public health and medical education until 1950.
Of particular interest in this series is a 30 volume manuscript survey and history of medical education in India by W. S. Carter (1926-1927).

During the 1930's and 1940's the Foundation supported various rural health programs, developmental aid to nursing, and a survey of librarianship during this period. From 1951 to 1971 the Foundation's main interest in India was expressed through its virus disease research program. Researchers should note that material covering virus research is filed under both 464 and 464 V.

The Foundation also funded public health and anti-malaria work in the independent Indian states of Mysore (464.1), Sawantwadi (464.4), and Travancore (464.5) from 1928 to 1944. After independence was granted India in 1947, these numerical designations were dropped from the Foundation's classification scheme.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation first gave attention to this area as part of its world-wide survey of medical education. From 1928 until 1950, the Foundation also funded projects in hookworm and malaria control, public sanitation, and museum training. Included in these records are correspondence, reports, and a diary by J. Austin Kerr (1944-1946).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries as follows:
485 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
485 H Hookworm
485 I Malaria
485 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
485 R Humanities and arts

odd.p: Actual dates for this series are: 1915, 1923-1924, 1926-1952, 1952.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records in this subseries refer to the sub-Saharan portion of the African continent, not simply to the Union of South Africa.

The Rockefeller Foundation's interest in this area was first expressed through study and support of medical education. The Foundation also provided travel grants in anatomy and anthropology, as well as general support for the South African Institute of International Affairs (Johannesburg).

487 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
487 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
487 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The main bulk of the material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's important program to combat yellow fever. The Foundation, through its West African Yellow Fever Commission, maintained research laboratories at Lagos, Nigeria and field offices throughout the region. These records contain correspondence, reports, a diary by the Commission's director, Henry Beeuwkes (1925-1934), and a set of case histories and medical records of yellow fever victims (1924-1930).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Three subseries as follows:
497 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
497 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
497 O Yellow fever

These records contain correspondence, reports, a diary by the Commission's director, Henry Beeuwkes (1925-1934), and a set of case histories and medical records of yellow fever victims (1924-1930).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grants to French institutions were made primarily in the medical sciences field. The earliest grants were awarded for the campaign against tuberculosis, from which the Foundation's nursing program was created. The University of Paris was the major recipient of grants for the medical sciences. Funds were given for work by Th. Alajouanine, Jean Scherrer, and Clovis Vincent in neurology and neurosurgery and by Georges Heuyer in psychiatry. Funding was given to the Radium Institute in the 1920's, 1930's, and 1940's. The University of Lyons and the University of Strasbourg were also recipients of a relatively large number of medical sciences grants. In addition, there are files dealing with the Pearce report on French medical education which was part of a report on medical education throughout the world.

The Rockefeller Foundation also gave funding to a full range of humanities and social sciences programs. A large number of grants were given for work in philosophy. Grants were also given for a broad range of studies including art history and geography and ethnology. A number of humanities and social sciences grants were made to refugee scholars, including Richard Alewyn (German Literature), Elias Bickermann (Greek archeology), Kurt Sachs (music history), Julius Lewy (Assyriology), and Paul Schrecker (Philosophy).
The American Library in Paris and the Bibliotheque Nationale also received Foundation support.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Twelve subseries as follows:
500 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
500 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
500 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
500 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
500 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
500 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
500 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
500 O Yellow fever
500 P Undulant fever
500 R Humanities and arts
500 S Social sciences
500 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest records of this series (1906-1910) are reports on education in the Far East, particularly in India, China, and Japan, examining the possibilities of establishing western educational systems there. Records from the 1930s-1940s report on the schools that were established, including the Peking Union Medical College, and the effect of medical education on Far Eastern demography. There is also material relating to the American Schools of Oriental Research in Bagdad and Jerusalem.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
600 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
600 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
600 E Fellowships, scholarships, and training awards
600 R Humanities and arts

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Scholarly access to original archival material is permitted. User copies of microfilm are also available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From 1913 to 1928 the Foundation's interests in China were directed by the China Medical Board, a division of the foundation. In 1928 the China Medical Board was separately incorporated and the functions continued by the Foundation were transferred to the Foundation's Division of Medical Education. Series 601 contains material after 1928, except for the Historical Records, which go back to 1913. Although the bulk of the material originated before 1945, there is also correspondence as late as 1960. The material consists of correspondence, memos, and reports relating to specific grants, and reports of a general nature which are filed in the 601 (General) section. A section on program and policy contains administrative and policy information in various forms.

Major areas of interest were agriculture and rural economics, public health and medicine. Grants were made predominantly to hospitals, universities and institutes of research. Of special interest are the files on rural reconstruction, the Mass Education movement, and the Peking Union Medical College.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
601 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
601 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
601 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
601 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
601 I Malaria
601 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
601 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
601 R Humanities and arts
601 S Social sciences
601 T Tuberculosis

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Scholarly access to original archival material is permitted. User copies of microfilm are also available.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For a more complete view of the Rockefeller Foundation's program in China the records of the China Medical Board, Record Group 4 and of the China Medical Board, Inc. Collection should be consulted. Correspondence and reports can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2.
See also - 6.1 Field Office-Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the material in this series relates to the development of medical sciences and natural sciences, generally through visiting professor grants, public health, and nursing. Institutions receiving aid include the Tokyo Institute of Public Health, Keio University, St. Luke's International Hospital, and the Tohoku Imperial University. There is also a 1921 report on medical education in Japan, part of the Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide survey of medical education, and a survey of medical education after World War II.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Six subseries as follows:
609 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
609 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
609 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
609 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
609 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
609 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest material in this series (1915) is a survey of medical education in Siam, part of the Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide survey of medical education. Most of the series consists of grants for visiting professors to Chulanlongkorn University and the development of nursing education at Siriraj Hospital.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of this series contains material relating to medical and natural sciences during the 1930's - 1940's. Prominent institutes are the University of Amsterdam, the University of Groningen, the University of Leiden, and the University of Utrecht. Projects included the University of Leiden Observatory, travel grants, and malaria. In the 1940's, Foundation aid to the social sciences and humanities increased, giving grants to museums, libraries, Far Eastern Studies, and economics.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Six subseries as follows:
650 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
650 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
650 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
650 I Malaria
650 R Humanities and arts
650 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of this series contains material relating to medical and natural sciences during the 1930's - 1940's. Prominent institutes are the University of Amsterdam, the University of Groningen, the University of Leiden, and the University of Utrecht. Projects included the University of Leiden Observatory, travel grants, and malaria. In the 1940's, Foundation aid to the social sciences and humanities increased, giving grants to museums, libraries, Far Eastern Studies, and economics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This material deals with The Rockefeller Foundation's activities in Europe and is concentrated in the 1940's. It includes 12 boxes of the Rockefeller Foundation's Health Commission records (1933-1956). There is also information concerned with the organization of The Rockefeller Foundation offices in Europe (1923-1963).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
700 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
700 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
700 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
700 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
700 I Malaria
700 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
700 R Humanities and arts
700 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material dealing with The Rockefeller Foundation's activities in Yugoslavia covers nine subject areas. There is a concentration of material in medical science (1920-1954), which covers grants to universities, a report of medical education in Yugoslavia, visits by scholars and educators, and public health. There is also material concerning nursing (1920-1950), which includes a report by F. Elisabeth Crowell, schools of nursing, and a travel grant.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material is divided into the following nine subseries:
710 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
710 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
710 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
710 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
710 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
710 I Malaria
710 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
710 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
710 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material concerned with The Rockefeller Foundation's activities in Czechoslovakia concentrates on medical science grant, most to institutions for study in specific areas of medicine (1920-1950), and Public Health surveys, local health departments and demonstrations. Also included is material dealing with Social Science.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material is divided into the following eight subseries:
712 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
712 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
712 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
712 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
712 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
712 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
712 R Humanities and arts
712 S Social sciences

Also included is material dealing with Social Science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material concerning activities by The Rockefeller Foundation in Scandinavia in concentrated with Agricultural Clubwork. There is also a report on public health in Scandinavia.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material is divided into the following four subseries:
716 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
716 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)

716 F Declinations (within program, or outside program but receiving more consideration than a flat declination, i.e. request circulated to a number of officers for opinion before declining; outside opinion solicited; considerable correspondence leading to the declination)
716 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material concerned with The Rockefeller Foundation's activities in Germany is concentrated in Medical Sciences, including research grants (1922-1950) to specific institutions for research in specific areas and reports on medical education and medical literature in Germany, and Natural Science grants to institutions and specific persons. Also of interest in the General Topic area is a Postwar Survey by both Robert J. Havighurst and Albert R. Mann, including supplements, diaries, and preliminary material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material is divided into the following nine subseries:
717 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
717 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
717 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
717 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
717 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards

717 F Declinations (within program, or outside program but receiving more consideration than a flat declination, i.e. request circulated to a number of officers for opinion before declining; outside opinion solicited; considerable correspondence leading to the declination)
717 I Malaria
717 R Humanities and arts
717 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records on Hungary document Foundation activity that almost exclusively related to medicine and public health. The University of Budapest received an extensive number of grants in such fields as pediatric medicine, phamacology, physiology and nursing. There is a file covering the work in biochemistry of Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, 1937 winner of the Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology. In the field of public health, the Foundation helped set up local health department in Godollo, Mezokovesd, Pecs, and Vac. There is also a grant, which ran from 1927 through 1931, to the State Hygienic Institute for a study on influenza.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
750 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
750 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
750 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
750 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
750 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
750 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
750 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
750 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health
750 M Respiratory diseases
750 S Social sciences

There is also a grant, which ran from 1927 through 1931, to the State Hygienic Institute for a study on influenza.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records on Hungary document Foundation activity that almost exclusively related to medicine and public health. The University of Budapest received an extensive number of grants in such fields as pediatric medicine, phamacology, physiology and nursing. There is a file covering the work in biochemistry of Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, 1937 winner of the Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology. In the field of public health, the Foundation helped set up local health department in Godollo, Mezokovesd, Pecs, and Vac. There is also a grant, which ran from 1927 through 1931, to the State Hygienic Institute for a study on influenza.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This material is concentrated in the 1930's and 1940's. Included is a public Health Survey of 1949. There are a number of Universities that the Rockefeller Foundation gave grants to covering the field of medical science (1920-1957). There are also reports by F. Elizabeth Crowell on nursing (1922, 1924), material dealing with natural science grants to universities, and reports on malaria.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following nine subseries:
751 No program letter General material which does fit into a particular program area
751 A Medical Sciences Research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings
751 C Nursing Nursing education, public health nursing
751 D Natural Sciences and Agriculture Research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture
751 I Malaria
751 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
751 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health
751 R Humanities and Arts
751 S Social Sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This material is concentrated in three topic areas; medical sciences, in which The Rockefeller Foundation gave most grants to specific universities in varied field (1925-1951), natural science, with the concentration being in grants made to the University of Oslo (1929-1955), and humanities (1945-1950).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The 767 series is divided into the following seven subseries:
767 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
767 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
767 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
767 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
767 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health
767 R Humanities and arts
767 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The files for Rockefeller Foundation activity in Rumania show a very strong involvement in medical, public health and nursing projects. Grants were made for medical research in anatomy and physiology. Projects were funded for the eradication of scarlet fever and malaria, for the work of the Cluj Institute of Hygiene and the Institute of Hygiene in Bucharest and for various local health department activities and public health demonstrations. The Bucharest and Cluj schools of nursing also received grants, the latter for public health nursing. There were also grants for work in psychology at the University of Cluj and for the Roumanian Institute of Social Science.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Nine subseries as follows:
783 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
783 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
783 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
783 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
783 G Scarlet fever, Hospital Administration
783 I Malaria
783 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
783 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
783 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rockefeller Foundation activity in Poland, as documented in these records, involved primarily the funding of biomedical research work, public health programs, and nursing. Biomedical research was funded at the Universities of Cracow, Lodz, Warsaw, and Wroclaw in such fields as neurology and neurosurgery, pathology, pediatrics, and physiology. Public health projects were funded in Bendzin, Lwow, Makotow, Skierniewice, Vilno, and Warszawa. Nursing programs were funded at the University of Cracow, for public health and bedside nursing, and at the Warsaw School of Nursing. There is a file on Richard M. Pearce's report on "Medical Education in Poland," which was part of a survey of medical education throughout the world.
There is a small amount of material relating to grants in the social sciences especially for economics studies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
789 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
789 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
789 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
789 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
789 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
789 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
789 R Humanities and arts
789 S Social sciences

did.unittitle: Institute of Hygiene (Warsaw) - Hirszfeld - (Typhoid Fever, Tuberculosis)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records relating to Foundation activity in Spain deal almost exclusively with public health matters. There are files documenting projects on eradication of hookworm in mines, the campaign against malaria, and the development of a Bureau of Sanitary Statistics and an Epidemiological Bureau. Public Health demonstration projects were started in Albacete, Caceres, and Vallecas. There are also files concerning an anti-smallpox campaign and the development of public health nursing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
795 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
795 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
795 B Smallpox
795 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing) 795 H Hookworm
795 I Malaria
795 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
795 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
795 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health
795 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation's interest in Sweden began in the mid-1920's but grants were not distributed until the 1930's. The major portion of the grants were distributed through four of Sweden's research institutions, especially the Karolinska Institute and the University of Stockholm. Grants were concentrated in the medical sciences and natural sciences. A large portion of these grants were made to support scientists who were forced to flee the political upheaval in Europe from the mid-1930's through the post-war years.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries, as follows:
800 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
800 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
800 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
800 R Humanities and arts
800 S Social sciences

did.unittitle: Gunn, Selskar M "Public Health in Sweden" Report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation's interest in Sweden began in the mid-1920's but grants were not distributed until the 1930's. The major portion of the grants were distributed through four of Sweden's research institutions, especially the Karolinska Institute and the University of Stockholm. Grants were concentrated in the medical sciences and natural sciences. A large portion of these grants were made to support scientists who were forced to flee the political upheaval in Europe from the mid-1930's through the post-war years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest files in this series relate to medical schools in Switzerland, part of the Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide study of medical education in the 1920's. Later grants to the Universities of Basel, Berne, Geneva and Zurich deal mostly with purchase of equipment for research in the natural sciences. Material from the later 1940's and 1950's primarily documents travel grants.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries, as follows:
803 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
803 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
803 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
803 R Humanities and arts
803 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation's proposed Near East Commission never visited that region due to unsettled conditions after World War I. Two studies of medical education in that area were conducted, however, in 1916 and 1924-1927.

804 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
804 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early Foundation interest in Turkey came in the areas of medical education and nursing. Grants were made in the 1920's and 1930's for various public health projects in Ankara and Istanbul. Support in the later 1940's came for a survey of nursing and a travel grant for a lecturer in economics.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Seven subseries as follows:
805 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
805 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
805 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
805 I Malaria
805 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
805 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health
805 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation's earliest activity in Israel (formerly Palestine) was in the fields of malaria and hookworm control. During the 1930's, the Foundation also sponsored refugee scholars who were placed on the faculty of Hebrew University. Later grants were made in the fields of jaundice research and sex research.

825 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
825 H Hookworm
825 I Malaria
825 R Humanities and arts
825 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With the exception of a few general reports on medical education, The Rockefeller Foundation's interest was channeled entirely through the American University of Beirut. The Foundation gave support to the University's Medical School (1920-1967), to its Arabic Studies program (1948-1953) and School of Nursing (1927-1941). Although the files contain considerable material concerning the University's Department of Sociology, including a textbook and yearbooks, there is no record of any Foundation grant for its support during this period.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries, as follows:
833 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
833 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
833 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
833 R Humanities and arts
833 S Social sciences
